116.appears_in: reprinted on p. 69 of Time for Action, by Robin Mazyck (M.A. Thesis, Michigan State University School of Journalism, 1998).
notes: Summary: Lt. Gray reports for his next assignment.

117.title: Jive Gray
117.author: Oliver Harrington
117.appears_in: reprinted on p. 69 of Time for Action, by Robin Mazyck (M.A. Thesis, Michigan State University School of Journalism, 1998).
notes: Summary: Jive Gray prepares for a night mission.

118.title: Jive Gray
118.author: Harrington
118.series: June 30, 1945) "Colonel, This Job is a Solid Killer"*
118.appears_in: reprinted on p. 74 of Time for Action, by Robin Mazyck (M.A. Thesis, Michigan State University School of Journalism, 1998).
notes: Summary: Jive tries a new jet airplane with Colonel Pushkin.

119.title: Jive Gray
119.author: Harrington
119.series: July 28, 1945) "From Over Here We Can Climb to the Top of the Hill and Look Them Cats Over"*
119.appears_in: reprinted on p. 74 of Time for Action, by Robin Mazyck (M.A. Thesis, Michigan State University School of Journalism, 1998).
notes: Summary: Gray and Pushkin land their jet plane to get a look at the strange bomber.

120.title: Jive Gray
120.author: Harrington
120.series: Aug. 4, 1945) "Of Course Der Iss No One Moving, Stupid Pigs. Ve Knew Dat You Vould Not Control Your Curiosity"*
120.appears_in: reprinted on p. 74 of Time for Action, by Robin Mazyck (M.A. Thesis, Michigan State University School of Journalism, 1998).
notes: Summary: Jive and Pushkin are captured by Germans.

121.title: Jive Gray
121.author: Ol Harrington
121.series: Aug. 18, 1945) "Well Ah Don't Like Yo' Kind of Folks, an' Tha's Why Ah'm Heah!"*
121.appears_in: reprinted on p. 75 of Time for Action, by Robin Mazyck (M.A. Thesis, Michigan State University School of Journalism, 1998).
notes: Summary: Jive Gray meets an American collaborator with the Nazis, a "Herr Burton" from Mississippi.

122.title: Jive Gray
122.author: Ol Harrington
122.series: Sept. 15, 1945) "Now Baby, Ah'm Goin' Show You How We Make His Kind Squeal Back Wh'ar Ah Come From"*
122.appears_in: reprinted on p. 80 of Time for Action, by Robin Mazyck (M.A. Thesis, Michigan State University School of Journalism, 1998).
notes: Summary: Burton prepares to torture Jive Gray, but Col. Pushkin knocks him cold with one punch.

123.title: Jive Gray
123.author: Ol Harrington
123.series: Sept. 22, 1945) "He's At About 10,000. How Can We Get That Old So-an'-So to Dig Us?"*
123.appears_in: reprinted on p. 75 of Time for Action, by Robin Mazyck (M.A. Thesis, Michigan State University School of Journalism, 1998).
notes: Summary: Jive spots a friendly plane, and Colonel Pushkin is going to signal the pilot with her compact.

124.heading: Jive Gray--Miscellanea.
124.title: Time for Action : World War II through the eyes of an African-American cartoonist
124.author: by Robin Mazyck.
notes: Thesis (M.A.)
Michigan State University. School of Journalism, 1998.
Includes bibliographical references (leaves 85-87).
Summary: A study of Oliver Harrington and his aviation adventure comic strip, Jive Gray (1943-1951).

136.title: "Jnaneshwar : Founder of the Bhakti Movement in Maharashtra"
136.author: script, S
136.appears_in: S. Apte ; illustrations, H.S. Chavan ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 723 (1978, 2009 printing).
notes: (Visionaries)
Begins: "One morning, towards the end of the thirteenth century, Siddhopant Kulkarni the chief officer of Alandi saw a young boy deep in meditation on the bank of the river Indrayani."

Summary from back cover: "It was predicted by a sage that the children of Vithal and Rukmini would be great spiritual leaders. But of their four children it was little Jnanadev who seemed to have a special inclination for the scriptures. In his brief life as a preacher Jnaneshwar, as he was called later, spread the message of Bhagwat Dharma or love of God and brotherhood of man. He was the founder of the Bhakti movement in Maharashtra. Jnaneshwar renounced the world at the age of twenty-one."

137.title: "J'nnn J'nnzz, Manhunter from Marzz : The Rebirth"

notes: Issue title: "Iron-Soul Stories"

138.title: The Jinx of the Lazy Y
notes: A western story serialized in Treasure Chest of Fun & Fact in 1949 and 1950. A credited episode is by Henry Gregor Felson and Ed Hunter.
